summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 among personnel at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding a discovery review project. The task involves reviewing email files to identify pages related solely to the conditions of confinement for Tartaglione or emails with an individual regarding Touhy, for the purpose of redaction. The correspondence references the Epstein case and damaged PDF files.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.role: Individual subject to conditions of confinement review
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a review to identify documents related to his conditions of confinement, separate from but potentially related to an Epstein incident.

events.title: Discovery review project initiation
events.description: A U.S. Attorney assigns a review of email files to identify pages related to Tartaglione's conditions of confinement or emails regarding Touhy for redaction.

events.title: Discovery review progress and issues
events.description: Reviewer provides an update, flags that two PDFs are damaged and cannot be opened, and submits a spreadsheet with flagged portions, noting some areas may relate to Tartaglione but are connected to Epstein or interview/preservation requests.

events.title: Replacement of corrupt files
events.description: Replacement files for two corrupt PDFs are provided in a shared directory, and the reviewer is asked to add them to an updated spreadsheet.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was conducting a discovery review project in October 2020 to identify documents for redaction related to Tartaglione's conditions of confinement and emails regarding Touhy.
The review specifically involved email files, and some documents were noted as potentially relating to Tartaglione but in connection to an Epstein incident or requests for interview/preservation.
Technical issues were encountered with two PDF files (Emails 2_Part4 and Emails 3_Part2) that were damaged and could not be opened, requiring replacements.
The correspondence indicates an administrative process within the DOJ to segregate and redact specific categories of information from discovery materials.
